Award.AwardTitle: Building an Inclusive Community of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Educators to Develop Competencies for Facilitating Biomolecular Visual Literacy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the structure of biomolecules is a critical component of understanding their function; this information is important in fields such as personalized medicine, agricultural production, and biofuels development. Molecular visualization, or the ability to understand three-dimensionality from two-dimensional representation, is a useful element in this building this understanding, yet few instructors teach or assess the skills needed to interpret two-dimensional images. This project will develop strategies and approaches to help students gain these important skills. In particular, the project will build a community of biochemistry and molecular biology educators who will help develop a set of competencies defining specific tasks that students will be expected to perform to develop their molecular visualization skills. Specifically, during the one-year term of this project, a series of national and regional workshops will be organized to develop a community of educators who are dedicated to the task of producing reliable and valid molecular visualization concept inventories. This group will develop a framework of goals and objectives for understanding four fundamental themes in molecular visualization - Monomer Recognition, Topology and Connectivity, Alternate Renderings, and Molecular Interactions. The group will also develop and populate a website with the competencies arising from the workshops.

This project will expand a framework established following an education symposium at the 2013 American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology meeting to include competencies that will ultimately lead to constructing concept inventories in molecular visualization. This project will focus on four fundamental themes: Monomer Recognition, Topology and Connectivity, Alternate Renderings, and Molecular Interactions. Understanding these four themes will build a foundation that allows students to comprehend the structure-function relationship inherent in biomolecules. Regional workshops will bring together educators to identify and reach a consensus on competencies within these four themes. These competencies will be added to the molecular visualization framework housed at http://cbm.msoe.edu/crest/molviz/ for public use. This project has already begun to transform the way many biochemistry and molecular biology instructors use molecular representations in their classroom. For example, several instructors understand the need to assess their students' comprehension of the representations of a particular model before they used the model to draw higher level inferences (e.g. function). In articulating consensus-based learning goals and objectives and identifying competencies, this project will identify the foundations upon which concept inventories will be developed in future years. Importantly, this effort will be built around workshops that establish a community of practice for the explicit instruction of molecular visualization skills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Biochemistry and molecular biology (BMB) education is often at the level of molecules, things so small that we can only observe them indirectly. BMB education, then, uses models to visualize these abstractions and to help students better understand how these molecules perform their functions. However, BMB educators seldom slow down and teach students how to read, interpret, and produce such images (collectively referred to as ?biomolecular visual literacy?), assuming instead that students glean this information from the larger context. Previously our group (BioMolViz) articulated a Molecular Visualization Framework, a chart of overarching themes, learning goals, and learning objectives for instructors to explicitly consider when using molecular models in their classrooms. The purpose of this award was to create a community of BMB educators who would use the Framework to develop assessments aimed at rectifying student misconceptions in the BMB classroom. These workshops have resulted in more than 180 unique assessments/activities, which are currently being vetted by our core working team. The work supported by this award has been the foundation of a newly-awarded a five-year Research Coordination Network in Undergraduate Biology Education (RCN-UBE) grant, which we will use to further widen our network and bring professional development to an ever-expanding community of BMB educators.

 

Broader impacts

During the course of the award, we have led seven workshops, each at unique institutions across the country. Our collective work has engaged over 80 BMB educators from 20 states. One explicit objective of this work was to engage a wider swath of biochemists, broadening the diversity and inclusion of the BMB education community. To that end, we held workshops in cities (St. Louis, Atlanta, Baltimore, San Diego) that would support faculty and trainees at historically black colleges and universities, Hispanic-serving institutions, and tribal colleges and universities. Moreover, many participants have become more engaged with their professional societies, such as the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (ASBMB), which often provide support and professional development opportunities for their members. From our workshops, we have found new partnerships, including the recruitment of five new biochemistry experts into our core BioMolViz team, broadening the expertise represented in our project.
